item.title: 24 inches by 24inches outside No.1, 1st November
item.description:
This was repaired a few years ago. The material that the contractors used has disappeared, The Surface has disappeared and left the stones which has caused a puncture on my motorbike also its leaving stones in my tyres, soon to have a puncture, some of them stones a pointed as the one removed from my motorbike tyre. The pavement has been deteriorating for quite a while now.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Bournewood Road, Poverest, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Crossing between Willesden Lane and Cavendish Road/The Avenue, 1st November
item.description:
Dear Sir/Madam My name is Laura Niada, and I am a resident of Queen’s Park. I am writing to raise a serious safety concern regarding the pedestrian crossing at the junction of The Avenue and Willesden Lane. The current traffic signal layout is as follows: - The signals allow traffic to flow diagonally: north-east to south-west, and north-west to south-east, alternating. - Pedestrians cross at the same time as the green light for the corresponding direction, but there is no dedicated pedestrian phase when all vehicles are stopped. - Turning vehicles must cross the pedestrian path, creating frequent conflicts. - Red asphalt markings indicate pedestrian paths, but they do not confer legal priority over vehicles turning across them. I cross this junction frequently with my children (one of whom uses crutches at the moment) and our dog. Every time we cross, we fear for our safety. On one occasion, while crossing with three children, one on crutches, and my dog, a driver refused to yield and made an obscene gesture, creating a frightening situation. The crossing is used by many pedestrians, including children and older residents. Jumping back onto the pavement to avoid turning vehicles is often impossible, especially if you have children, dogs, a disability, or are simply not very quick and agile, and cars often turn without indicating until the last moment. The combination of diagonal vehicle flows, lack of a dedicated pedestrian phase, and driver disregard makes this crossing extremely hazardous. I respectfully request that Brent Council introduce a dedicated pedestrian phase (“green man” signal) so pedestrians can cross safely when all vehicles are stopped and/or install additional signage, road markings, or traffic-calming measures to emphasise pedestrian priority. I urge you to treat this crossing as a high-priority safety concern. Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your response outlining how the Council plans to review and address this dangerous crossing. Yours faithfully, Dr Laura Niada Laurania2017@gmail.com 44A Winchester Avenue NW6 7TU London
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 162, Willesden Lane, Brondesbury, London
Report on FixMyStreet
